column1: How many active California fires with 10,000 or more acres burned will be reported by the LA Times' California Fire Map as of 1 October 2020?
column6: ['Society', 'Environment']
Still about 17 active fires of that size 4 days out.

Four days left. 16 active 10k+ acre fires and one more growing close. 3 are 98% contained but even optimistically that brings us from 16 to 13. No heavy rains anticipated according to NOAA. If there were, I'm guessing fires take longer than 4 days to be contained even with the help of rain.

Based on the rate at which fires dropped off the list between 9/20 (the date of my first estimate) and now, the date of my latest estimate, I see almost zero chance of there being less than 4 fires on that list.

I predict there will be 10 active fires (+2/-2) with more than 10,000 or more acres burned on 01 October 2020 with a certainty of 90%. There seems to be a borderline between those fires that started in September and have got contained to a large degree very fast, and those fires that have been burning for 40 days or more and that have mostly burned 100,000 acres or more, when it comes to "containability". As soon as a fire has crossed 100,000 it appears it keeps burning for several reasons, such as a lack of water for containment or as a natural barrier, the geographical structure that promotes stronger winds, the type of local woods or vegetation that is affected and maybe even the impassable landscape. It seems resources like firefighting planes are allocated to fresh fires in order to put out fires before they grow too large to be contained easily, imho, and of course to places where people's lives and livelihoods are in acute danger. The fact that even large fire complexes such as
Latest data from LA Times: The most recent fire is the Wolf fire, which started on Sept. 22. It is 35% contained and has burned 1,087 acres so far.
Latest data from LA Times: The most recent fire is the Wolf fire, which started on Sept. 22. It is 25% contained and has burned 1,077 acres so far.
No rain until Wednesday 30 September 2020. It remains between a rock and a hard place.
Given the fire data, I do not see the number dropping below 4, but I'm keeping the other options open to account for possible rainstorms.
There are currently (9/20/2020) about 12 fires that are near 10k acres and less than 62% contained. This does not bode well for dropping below 4.
Summary: >4 seems almost certain at this point but I would only feel comfortable with a 90% if I were more experienced in subject matter.
Latest data from LA Times: The most recent fire is the Snow fire, which started on Sept. 17. It is 20% contained and has burned 6,013 acres so far.

The operative word is active. If they are 100% contained they are no longer active. The question becomes how long does it take to contain them? U.S. wildfire seasons now last an average 76 days longer than in the 1970s and 1980s. Before 1986, a wildfire was contained on average in less than eight days. Since then, the average wildfire has burned for 37 days. facethefactsusa.org â€º facts â€º the-nati...

Creek Fire - Full containment not expected until October 15: https://www.capradio.org/articles/2020/09/17/latest-updates-on-northern-california-wildfires/ Bobcat not until 30 Oct: https://abc7.com/bobcat-fire-evacuation-warnings-issued-for-juniper-hills-area/6428568/ Therefore 0 and 1 are now fully at zero.
Latest data from LA Times:
Based on the maps themselves and how many fires continue to burn now. The amount of rain expected a big factor.
No amounts of precipitation worth mentioning to be expected for CA by 26 September 2020.

On the one hand, the number of fires that are both 10,000+ acres and less than 50% contained is down to 8. Less than a week ago, it was 12. So things are still on track to get below 4 by the end of the month.
Updated by 1%

Northern California is predicted to get rain at the end of this week, which should help with the Red Salmon Complex and other fires up there. The number of wildfires that are both over 10k acres and under 50% contained is now at 11, down from 12 yesterday. Adjusting odds accordingly.
Latest data from LA Times:

I just found a resource by the NOAA, the "Rapid Refresh" imagery for relative humidity in the 850hPa surface. It sadly confirms my view that there's virtually no chance any time soon for any rainfalls, since the entire Pacific coast and even large areas offshore are covered with a bowl of extremely dry air, which has an unusually low relative humidity of 20% or less.
Currently 20 active ðŸ”¥. Average age for this time of month was 4 with average of late September as 2. We're now looking at 16 and 20 active so far.
It looks as if the fires might be migrating to Oregon, probably on account of the high taxes in California. Staying pretty high though, on account of stragglers.

The actual current number is 12, because those are fires that are both: 1) 10,000+ acres 2) Less than 50% contained There are 20 days remaining. @aharm posted that these fires take an average of 2.5 weeks to put out, so presumably the map will look much different toward the end of the month. Rain is coming soon to the northernmost part of California next week: https://weather.com/forecast/regional/news/2020-09-09-wildfire-relief-weather-pattern-change-washington-oregon

Learned from 2019 fire season: - there were only 4 fires that were above 10,000 acres (so today's 20 fires is high above normal - even last year was considered high) - on average, the 4 10,000+ acre fires were put out in about 2.5 weeks after the start date
I don't take any satisfaction in this update. It's really awful what's happing out there. Tracking the reported numbers for the past 5 days increases my confidence that there will be 4 or more....

Crowd is overconfident on something that is fat-tailed. Best I can tell, the winning number for 1 Oct. 2019 would have been 0: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_California_wildfires This is a record-breaking season to be sure, but for all we know things could revert to the mean for the rest of September (e.g., rains could pick up as historically happens in late Sept, etc.) This NPR segment gives a good overview of what's going on right now: https://www.npr.org/2020/09/04/909668879/whats-driving-california-s-biggest-ever-wildfire-season
Currently 23 active fires over 10,000 acres. Only 7 are 80%+ contained. Even accounting for weather, unlikely will fall under less than 4.
Latest data from LA Times:
re-adjusting for the crowd....

I have 4 days of data at this point, and while I haven't done any math with it (a project for next week once I have more data), it seems that its more likely than not that there will still be 4 such fires burning by the deadline.
"Active" and 10,000 acres are the key words. Although there are still many fires in October, most are 500 to 5000 acres.

Seems to take ~~20-40 days to contain a fire lazily looking at the panel, and ~6 fires over 10k with little containment - so not crazy the existing set of fires will put in the top bucket without any additions. Per @cnesky, seem to be off on the tail of the reference class.

In my last post I didn't have this year's data yet. I've added it and am now adjusting my estimate toward the higher end to make my mode the average rounded up of 3. Overall https://rpubs.com/cneskey/fires2020
Fires of the 9.5k+ acre (some padding to 10k) magnitude seem to drop in September then get worse in October, generally toward the end of October (https://rpubs.com/cneskey/fires).
I'm having a hard time deciding how confident I am about the top bucket. Also/equivalently whether there is value in putting any probability on the lower buckets.
Latest data from LA Times: 43 fires overall; 15 fires at 10,000+ acres, 6 fires at 75%+ containment.
Doing it

I've taken the data from the LA Times map provided in the description and plotted it in Numbers. Every day I'll update it in order to track rate of spread, and rate of containment. This should help provide a better forecast over the next week.
This is an interesting question on a topic I know nothing about.

I have looked at the LA Fire Map which is extremely helpful from the question and thanks to Casey Miller for putting that together. I am asking her if she can add some data to her tracker for this question or access to specific data-streams, might make it easier, worth a try.

Vegetation is supposed to be very dry, daily maximum temperatures in CA will range from 34Â°C (northern CA) to 45Â°C (south-east corner of CA) until at least Thursday 10 September 2020, and zero precipitation to be expected for whole CA until at least Sunday 13 September 2020. Most wildfires this season are the result of lightning during thunderstorms, so we are basically talking about a very low probability of additional wildfires through that way of ignition which could grow to 10,000 or more acres. The questions then would be: /for how long will each individual of the current fires go on burning before it will be extinct and considered no longer active? /how many of the remaining fires <10,000 acres (currently 29, 16 of which have a "containment" status 10% to 98%, 13 have no such status and either lack detailed info or are already considered as contained) will reach the required criteria by 01 October 2020, and will remain active as well? However, there are other causes for wildfires to start, most importantly human intent, and technical (or human) failure. The 2018 Camp Fire (153,336 acres burned, "was the deadliest and most destructive wildfire in California history") was almost surely ignited by faulty power lines belonging to the utility company Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camp_Fire_%282018%29 Drought as a precondition of wildfires will thus advance additional wildfires which will be ignited in other ways than lightning. Severe winds or fire storms will determine, how fast the affected area will grow. So far winds are likely to play a subordinated role.
Active CA fires >10,000 acres as of 1 September 2020: 14
